description:
8.21 aexciter
An exciter is used to produce high sound that is not present in the
original signal. This is done by creating harmonic distortions of the
signal which are restricted in range and added to the original signal.
An Exciter raises the upper end of an audio signal without simply raising
the higher frequencies like an equalizer would do to create a more
"crisp" or "brilliant" sound.

The filter accepts the following options:
name: aexciter

options.description: Set input level prior processing of signal. Allowed range is from 0 to 64. Default value is 1.
options.name: level_in

options.description: Set output level after processing of signal. Allowed range is from 0 to 64. Default value is 1.
options.name: level_out

options.description: Set the amount of harmonics added to original signal. Allowed range is from 0 to 64. Default value is 1.
options.name: amount

options.description: Set the amount of newly created harmonics. Allowed range is from 0.1 to 10. Default value is 8.5.
options.name: drive

options.description: Set the octave of newly created harmonics. Allowed range is from -10 to 10. Default value is 0.
options.name: blend

options.description: Set the lower frequency limit of producing harmonics in Hz. Allowed range is from 2000 to 12000 Hz. Default is 7500 Hz.
options.name: freq

options.description: Set the upper frequency limit of producing harmonics. Allowed range is from 9999 to 20000 Hz. If value is lower than 10000 Hz no limit is applied.
options.name: ceil

options.description: Mute the original signal and output only added harmonics. By default is disabled.
options.name: listen
